study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of omega-3 fatty acids (including docosahexaenoic acid) combined with vitamin E on subjective global assessment scores and metabolic profiles in chronic hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that combined omega-3 fatty acids (containing docosahexaenoic acid) and vitamin E supplementation significantly improved SGA scores, fasting plasma glucose, serum insulin levels, insulin resistance, and insulin sensitivity compared to placebo or individual supplements.
population_specificity: Chronic hemodialysis patients (n=120).
effective_dosage: 1250 mg/day omega-3 fatty acids (containing 300 mg docosahexaenoic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing intake of DHA and EPA through supplementation improves cognition and mood in individuals with cognitive impairment no dementia (CIND) or Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: The study found that elevating depleted levels of EPA and DHA through supplementation had negligible beneficial effects on cognition or mood in individuals with CIND or AD, confirming an overall negligible benefit of omega-3 PUFA supplementation for cognitive impairment and dementia.
population_specificity: Individuals with cognitive impairment no dementia (CIND) or Alzheimer's disease (AD).
effective_dosage: 600 mg EPA and 625 mg DHA per day.

study_goal: To determine whether supplementation with EPA+DHA reduces common biomarkers of chronic, systemic inflammation in healthy individuals.
results_summary: Supplementation with 1400 mg EPA+DHA did not reduce serum CRP or IL-6 levels or alter ex vivo pro-inflammatory cytokine production in healthy adults.
population_specificity: 261 healthy individuals aged 30-54 years with low baseline EPA+DHA intake (≤300 mg/day) and no inflammatory conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if DHA supplementation could slow vision loss in males with X-linked retinitis pigmentosa (XLRP).
results_summary: DHA supplementation significantly increased blood DHA levels and reduced the rate of progression in dark-adapted thresholds and visual field sensitivity, but no differences were found in visual acuity, shape discrimination, or fundus appearance.
population_specificity: Males aged 7-31 years with XLRP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of DHA supplementation versus nutrition education on increasing DHA consumption and its impact on gestational length.
results_summary: Supplementation with 600 mg DHA per day or nutrition education significantly increased gestational length by 4.0-4.5 days. Each 1% increase in RBC DHA at delivery was associated with a 1.6-day increase in gestational length, and DHA supplementation reduced early preterm birth rates.
population_specificity: Pregnant women aged 18-40, recruited between 16 and 20 weeks of gestation.
effective_dosage: 300 mg or 600 mg DHA per day.
study_duration: From recruitment (16-20 weeks of gestation) until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different omega-6/omega-3 ratios, specifically the impact of arachidonic acid and docosahexaenoic acid, on neurodevelopment in very preterm infants.
results_summary: Infants receiving formula with a 2:1 omega-6/omega-3 ratio had higher blood levels of essential fatty acids and better psychomotor development at 24 months compared to those receiving a 1:1 ratio. The 2:1 group's developmental scores were similar to those of breastfed controls.
population_specificity: Very preterm newborns (<1500 g and/or <32 weeks gestational age).
effective_dosage: Not specified (formula with ω-6/ω-3 ratios of 2:1 and 1:1).
study_duration: First year of life, with follow-up until 24 months corrected age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether krill oil supplementation (containing docosahexaenoic acid) affects post-exercise immune function and performance in healthy individuals.
results_summary: Krill oil supplementation increased PBMC IL-2 production and NK cell cytotoxic activity 3h post-exercise but did not affect exercise performance, plasma IL-6, TBARS, or other cytokine levels.
population_specificity: Healthy young males and females (age 25.8 ± 5.3 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical role of n-3 PUFA, particularly docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), in preventing atrial fibrillation (AF) and explore potential underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Circulating DHA was inversely associated with AF risk, while EPA showed no effect. n-3 PUFA supplementation showed no benefit in most post-cardiac surgery AF studies, but a four-week pretreatment reduced AF incidence after cardioversion.
population_specificity: Patients at risk of or with atrial fibrillation, including post-cardiac surgery patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) supplementation could attenuate chronic pulmonary apoptosis in a mouse model of perinatal inflammation and postnatal hyperoxia.
results_summary: Maternal DHA supplementation significantly reduced pulmonary apoptosis in hyperoxia-exposed mice, even 8 weeks after returning to room air. The findings suggest DHA offers protective effects against chronic lung damage from adverse perinatal and neonatal events.
population_specificity: Pregnant mice and their offspring exposed to perinatal inflammation and postnatal hyperoxia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent literature on the health aspects of n-3 fatty acid intake from fish or supplements and discuss reasons for conflicting findings.
results_summary: The study found broad consensus that fish and seafood are optimal sources of n-3 fatty acids, with recommended consumption of 2-3 servings per week. Evidence for benefits from n-3 supplementation has diminished, likely due to increased seafood consumption and better pharmacological interventions for cardiovascular diseases.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on cardiovascular disease patients.
effective_dosage: Approximately 2-3 servings of fish/seafood per week (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether DHA supplementation could prevent or reduce PTSD symptoms in patients after severe accidental injury.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in PTSD symptoms between the DHA and placebo groups at 3-month follow-up, with 11.1% of the DHA group and 5.5% of the placebo group developing PTSD. DHA supplementation did significantly increase erythrocyte levels of DHA and EPA compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Accident-injured patients admitted to an intensive care unit in Tokyo, Japan.
effective_dosage: 1,470 mg/d of DHA plus 147 mg/d of EPA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory effects of omega-3 fatty acids (DHA and EPA) in the placenta and adipose tissue of overweight/obese pregnant women.
results_summary: Supplementation with DHA and EPA significantly increased plasma levels of these fatty acids, reduced CRP concentrations, and decreased inflammatory markers (TLR4, IL6, IL8, TNFα) in both adipose tissue and placenta. In vitro, DHA and EPA suppressed palmitate-induced inflammation in adipose and trophoblast cells.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese pregnant women
effective_dosage: 2 g/day (DHA plus EPA), administered twice daily
study_duration: From week 10-16 of pregnancy to term (>25 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of ω-3 fatty acid supplementation, including docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), on in vivo glutathione (GSH) concentration in older adults at risk for depression.
results_summary: The study found that ω-3 FA supplementation attenuated oxidative stress mechanisms, as evidenced by a lower increase in the GSH-to-creatine ratio in the thalamus compared to placebo, which was associated with worsening depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: Older adults at risk for depression (n=51).
effective_dosage: 800 mg DHA daily (as part of a total 2000 mg ω-3 FA supplement, including 1200 mg EPA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in maternal fatty acid status from pregnancy to 12 months postpartum and evaluate the impact of seafood consumption on fatty acid levels, particularly DHA.
results_summary: The study found that maternal DHA status declines during pregnancy and lactation but begins to recover around six months postpartum. Seafood and EPA/DHA supplement intake predicted higher DHA levels over time, though median seafood intake was lower than recommended.
population_specificity: Pregnant and postpartum women (n = 118).
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency of seafood and EPA/DHA-supplement intake was noted).
study_duration: 15 months (from gestation week 28 to 12 months postpartum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a daily omega-3 fatty acid supplement (containing docosahexaenoic acid) on dry eye symptoms, tear production, stability, and conjunctival cytology in young and middle-aged visual display terminal users.
results_summary: The study found that 2,400 mg/day of omega-3 fatty acids significantly improved dry eye symptoms, tear stability, and conjunctival cytology after 45 days, but did not significantly affect tear production. No significant changes were observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Young and middle-aged visual display terminal (VDT) users with dry eye symptoms.
effective_dosage: 2,400 mg/day (4 capsules twice daily, each containing 180 mg eicosapentaenoic acid and 120 mg docosahexaenoic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in brain development and its association with neurodevelopmental disorders.
results_summary: The study found that DHA is crucial for brain development, influencing neural cell processes and accumulating in learning and memory-related brain areas. It also linked low DHA levels to disorders like autism and ADHD, suggesting potential benefits of supplementation.
population_specificity: General human brain development and neurodevelopmental disorders (e.g., dyslexia, autism, ADHD, schizophrenia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether EPA and/or DHA supplementation improves cognitive performance in elderly individuals with dementia and/or Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: EPA and/or DHA supplementation did not significantly affect cognitive test scores overall but improved verbal fluency and attention in patients with very mild dementia or AD or those with APOEε4 negative genotype. No cognitive decline reduction was observed in advanced AD patients.
population_specificity: Elderly over 65 years with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease or dementia, including both genders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in preventing or delaying cognitive decline in early-stage Alzheimer's disease (AD) by examining human evidence from epidemiological, dietary intervention, and supplementation studies.
results_summary: The study found that DHA supplementation can reduce markers of inflammation and that lower DHA levels are associated with AD, suggesting potential benefits in early-stage AD. However, longer-term trials are needed to confirm these effects.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals, particularly those with or at risk of early-stage Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of prenatal DHA supplementation on offspring development at 18 months of age in a population with low DHA intake.
results_summary: Prenatal DHA supplementation showed no significant effects on psychomotor or mental development indices or behavior rating scores at 18 months, though there may be some benefit for infants from poor-quality home environments. The study found no statistically significant differences between the DHA and control groups in developmental outcomes.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in Cuernavaca, Mexico, with low DHA intake, and their offspring (n = 730).
study_duration: Administered during the latter half of pregnancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of omega-3 supplementation (including docosahexaenoic acid), with or without vitamin E, on oxidative biomarkers and lipid profiles in women with dyslipidemia transitioning through menopause.
results_summary: Fish oil plus vitamin E significantly reduced total cholesterol and LDL-C after 90 days, while fish oil alone increased plasma TBARS concentrations (a marker of oxidative stress). All effects were independent of ethnic group.
population_specificity: Nonwhite and white women with dyslipidemia transitioning through menopause.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how EPA and DHA supplementation affects fatty acid composition in different blood lipid pools and cell membranes.
results_summary: The study found dose-dependent increases in EPA and DHA levels, accompanied by decreases in n-6 PUFAs in most pools, with oleic acid compensating in triglycerides. The n-6:n-3 PUFA ratio was significantly reduced across all pools after 12 months.
population_specificity: Not specified (general supplementation study)
effective_dosage: Equivalent to 0-4 portions of oily fish/week (1 portion: 3.27 g EPA+DHA)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Aterofisiol (containing DHA, among other components) could reduce lipid content in atherosclerotic plaques and neurological symptoms in patients with carotid stenosis.
results_summary: The study found that Aterofisiol significantly reduced lipid content in plaques and lowered the incidence of neurological symptoms compared to placebo, with statistical significance (P<0.05).
population_specificity: Patients with carotid stenosis >70% undergoing carotid endarterectomy (135 men and 79 women).
effective_dosage: One tablet of Aterofisiol every 24 hours (exact DHA dosage not specified).
study_duration: 30 days before surgery, stopped 5 days prior.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and other omega-3 fatty acids exert anti-inflammatory and pro-resolving effects, particularly in the context of inflammatory diseases like rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The study found that DHA and related omega-3 fatty acids produce bioactive lipid mediators (resolvins, protectins, and maresins) that actively regulate inflammation resolution, demonstrating benefits such as reduced joint pain, morning stiffness, and NSAID usage in rheumatoid arthritis patients.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis patients (specific sample size not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether DHA supplementation increases serum BDNF levels and whether changes in BDNF levels are associated with PTSD and depression symptoms in severely injured patients.
results_summary: DHA supplementation did not specifically increase serum BDNF or pro-BDNF levels compared to placebo, but increased BDNF and pro-BDNF levels were negatively associated with depression severity, suggesting a protective effect. No association was found between BDNF changes and PTSD symptoms.
population_specificity: Severely injured patients vulnerable to PTSD and depression.
effective_dosage: 1470 mg DHA plus 147 mg EPA per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether fish oil supplementation, including docosahexaenoic acid, could prevent or reduce the severity of osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Laboratory and canine studies showed promising anti-inflammatory and joint lubrication effects, but human clinical trials yielded inconsistent results. The study concluded that more well-designed trials are needed to confirm potential benefits.
population_specificity: Humans (clinical trials), canines (trials), and in vitro studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between red blood cell n-3 DPA levels and markers of inflammation (IL-6, TNF-α, CRP) and fasting triglycerides, as well as the dose-response effects of n-3 fatty acid supplementation on RBC n-3 DPA.
results_summary: RBC n-3 DPA was inversely correlated with CRP and fasting TG in both studies, and n-3 supplementation significantly increased RBC n-3 DPA dose-dependently, with greater relative increases in Study 1 (29%-61%) compared to Study 2 (14%-26%).
population_specificity: Study 1: 115 participants aged 20-44, BMI 20-30 kg/m², TG 34-176 mg/dL; Study 2: 28 participants aged 22-65, BMI 24-37 kg/m², TG 141-339 mg/dL.
effective_dosage: Study 1: 0, 300, 600, 900, and 1800 mg/day EPA + DHA; Study 2: 0, 850, and 3400 mg/day EPA + DHA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether DHA supplementation could rectify the reduced DHA levels in maternal and fetal phospholipids caused by gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: Daily supplementation of 600 mg DHA significantly enhanced maternal DHA levels in plasma and red blood cell phospholipids but did not improve fetal DHA status. Neonatal anthropometric measurements were comparable between the supplemented and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and their neonates.
effective_dosage: 600 mg DHA daily (two capsules of DHA-enriched formula).
study_duration: From diagnosis of GDM until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether genetic susceptibility influences the response to DHA supplementation in preventing choroidal new vessels (CNV) in patients with early age-related maculopathy.
results_summary: The study found a protective effect of DHA supplementation among homozygous non-risk patients for CFH Y402H, with CNV occurrence significantly lower in the DHA group (16.7%) compared to placebo (38.2%). No statistically significant increased risk for CNV was observed in patients carrying risk alleles for CFH Y402H or ARMS2 A69S.
population_specificity: Patients aged 55-85 years with early age-related maculopathy, visual acuity better than 0.4 Logarithm of Minimum Angle of Resolution units in the study eye, and neovascular AMD in the fellow eye.
effective_dosage: 3 daily fish-oil capsules, each containing 280 mg DHA, 90 mg EPA, and 2 mg Vitamin E.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a six-week supplementation with DHA on gene expression in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) compared to EPA and olive oil.
results_summary: DHA supplementation increased plasma phospholipid DHA by 63% but did not significantly affect gene expression pathways, unlike EPA, which showed notable changes in multiple pathways including interferon signaling and cAMP-mediated signaling.
population_specificity: Subjects receiving DHA (n=18), EPA (n=16), or olive oil (n=16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of iron supplementation combined with docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) on cardiovascular disease risk markers in women with iron deficiency anemia (IDA).
results_summary: The study found that DHA supplementation reduced serum hs-CRP levels, indicating a potential anti-inflammatory effect, but did not significantly affect PON-1 or the ApoB/ApoA-I ratio. The placebo group showed a decrease in ApoA-I, while DHA did not.
population_specificity: Women aged 15-45 years with iron deficiency anemia.
effective_dosage: 500 mg of DHA supplement once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in modulating stress response and brain development, and its potential as a prenatal nutritional intervention for improving offspring mental health.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that prenatal exposure to high glucocorticoids may negatively affect fetal development and later emotional regulation, and that DHA could play a role in mitigating these effects. It highlights the potential of DHA as a perinatal preventive intervention for reducing childhood mental disorders.
population_specificity: Pregnant women living in poverty and their offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fish-oil supplementation, including docosahexaenoic acid, on cytokine production and Th cell phenotype in elite paddlers undergoing intense exercise.
results_summary: Fish-oil supplementation decreased TNF-α and IL-1β production, increased IL-6 and IL-10, reduced IFN-γ, and shifted Th cell balance toward a Th2 phenotype. No change was observed in IL-4 secretion.
population_specificity: Male elite paddlers
effective_dosage: 6 g/day of fish-oil capsules (containing 1.2 g docosahexaenoic acid and 2.4 g eicosapentaenoic acid)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of dietary fatty acids, particularly Docosahexaenoic Acid (DHA), on sperm fatty acid profiles and sperm quality parameters.
results_summary: The study found that DHA is a predominant PUFA in human sperm cells, with higher concentrations in the sperm head. Dietary omega-3 PUFA, including DHA, positively influenced sperm parameters after more than 4 weeks of supplementation, though responses varied by dose and duration. Elevated saturated or trans fatty acids and low DHA levels were associated with negative effects on sperm quality.
population_specificity: Human males, with a focus on fertile and infertile men.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential role of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in reducing breast cancer risk and improving outcomes in breast cancer survivors, including effects on inflammation, cognitive dysfunction, and chemotherapy-related side effects.
results_summary: The study suggests that higher intake ratios of DHA and EPA relative to arachidonic acid may reduce breast cancer risk through mechanisms like reducing proinflammatory derivatives and inhibiting cytokine production, but results from primary prevention trials are still pending. DHA supplementation is also being explored for mitigating post-diagnosis issues like cardiac dysfunction and chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy.
population_specificity: Women, particularly those at risk of or diagnosed with breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a 26-week EPA + DHA intervention in reducing symptom severity and relapse rates in first-episode schizophrenia patients compared to placebo.
results_summary: The abstract describes a planned study, so no results are reported yet. The study intends to assess symptom severity, relapse rates, and correlates of change, but findings are not yet available.
population_specificity: First-episode schizophrenia patients aged 16-35.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the distribution of ω-3 PUFAs (including docosahexaenoic acid) in HDL and LDL particles is influenced by APOE genotype before and after supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that ω-3 PUFA content in HDL and LDL was not significantly influenced by APOE genotype, but E4+ participants had higher ω-6/ω-3 ratios in LDL pre- and post-supplementation. DHA in HDL correlated with HDL-C levels only in E4- participants.
population_specificity: 80 participants aged 20-35 years, divided into E4+ (N=10) and E4- (N=70) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prenatal DHA supplementation affects offspring growth (weight, length, and BMI) through 60 months of age.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in height, weight, or BMI between children whose mothers received DHA supplementation and those who received a placebo, indicating no effect of prenatal DHA on postnatal growth.
population_specificity: Pregnant Mexican women and their offspring.
study_duration: From week 18-22 of gestation through delivery

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of DHA and/or EPA supplementation during chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy on treatment outcomes in oncologic patients.
results_summary: The study found that combining omega-3 fatty acids (DHA/EPA) with conventional chemotherapy was beneficial, particularly in preserving body composition, but did not observe significant effects on tumor size reduction or prolonged survival. No studies reported worse outcomes for supplement patients.
population_specificity: Oncologic patients undergoing chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: 600 mg to 3.6 g daily of EPA and/or DHA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between dietary and supplemental intake of omega-3 PUFAs (including DHA) and plasma levels in older adults.
results_summary: Fish oil supplement users had significantly higher plasma EPA and DHA levels compared to non-users. Dietary intake of n-3 PUFAs was associated with plasma levels, but most participants could not meet recommended EPA and DHA intake without supplements.
population_specificity: 73 community-dwelling older adults (23 men, 50 women) aged around 70 years in Tasmania, Australia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study assessed dietary and supplemental intake generally).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an RUTF with elevated short-chain n-3 PUFA, with or without fish oil supplementation, could improve children's PUFA status during treatment for severe acute malnutrition.
results_summary: Erythrocyte DHA content declined in groups not receiving fish oil, while the fish oil group showed significantly higher DHA and EPA levels. The study concluded that current RUTF formulations do not meet PUFA requirements without additional preformed long-chain n-3 PUFA.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 to 50 months with severe acute malnutrition in rural Kenya.
effective_dosage: Not specified (fish oil capsules were used but dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of flaxseed oil (rich in ALA) on cardiovascular risk factors, specifically serum small dense LDL (sd-LDL) concentrations, compared to corn oil.
results_summary: Flaxseed oil supplementation significantly reduced sd-LDL concentrations at 4 and 12 weeks compared to corn oil, particularly in subjects with triglyceride levels >100 mg/dl. No significant changes in docosahexaenoic acid concentrations were observed between the two periods.
population_specificity: 15 subjects in a randomized, double-blind, crossover study.
effective_dosage: 10 g of flaxseed oil or corn oil once daily with dinner.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether genetic factors (SNPs in PLA2 genes) influence plasma triglyceride levels in response to n-3 PUFA supplementation, including docosahexaenoic acid (DHA).
results_summary: The study found that n-3 PUFA supplementation independently reduced plasma triglyceride levels, and specific SNPs in PLA2 genes influenced both baseline triglyceride levels and the response to supplementation.
population_specificity: 208 subjects (demographics not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-dose LCPUFA supplementation (including DHA) corresponding to general dietary intake levels could improve cognitive function in non-demented elderly Japanese men.
results_summary: The study found that low-dose LCPUFA supplementation (DHA, EPA, and ARA) significantly improved cognitive function, as measured by P300 latency changes, compared to placebo. Plasma phospholipid levels of DHA and ARA increased in the supplemented group, while no changes were observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Non-demented elderly Japanese men aged 55-64 years.
effective_dosage: DHA (300 mg/day), EPA (100 mg/day), and ARA (120 mg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combined vitamin D and omega-3 PUFA (including docosahexaenoic acid) supplementation could improve airway function and reduce inflammation in recreational athletes with exercise-induced bronchoconstriction.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in lung function decline post-exercise between the usual diet, placebo, and supplementation groups. Serum vitamin D levels also remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Recreational athletes with exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether plasma omega-3 fatty acid concentrations, including docosahexaenoic acid, modify the effect of B vitamin supplementation on brain atrophy rates in elderly individuals with mild cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The study found that B vitamin treatment significantly slowed brain atrophy rates only in subjects with high baseline omega-3 fatty acid levels (>590 μmol/L), showing a 40% reduction compared to placebo. No significant effect was observed in those with low omega-3 levels (<390 μmol/L).
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (≥70 years) with mild cognitive impairment.
effective_dosage: Not specified for docosahexaenoic acid (only baseline plasma concentrations were measured).
interactions: Interaction noted between B vitamin treatment and plasma omega-3 fatty acids (eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of n-3 PUFA supplementation, including docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), on plasma adiponectin levels in end-stage renal disease (ESRD) patients.
results_summary: The study found an inverse correlation between baseline adiponectin levels and plasma DHA and EPA levels, but supplementation with n-3 PUFAs for 3 months did not significantly change adiponectin levels. The negative result may be due to the relatively low dose used.
population_specificity: 162 ESRD patients (mean age 67 ± 13 years, 56 women and 106 men) undergoing chronic hemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with omega-3 fatty acids (EPA/DHA) improves ADHD symptoms and cognitive control in young boys with and without ADHD.
results_summary: EPA/DHA supplementation improved parent-rated attention in both ADHD and typically developing children but had no effect on cognitive control or fMRI measures of brain activity. Phospholipid DHA levels increased in the supplemented group compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Boys aged 8-14 years, including 40 with ADHD and 39 typically developing controls.
effective_dosage: 650 mg EPA and 650 mg DHA daily, delivered via 10 g of enriched margarine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), alone or combined with iron, affected absenteeism and illness in iron-deficient schoolchildren with low fish intake.
results_summary: DHA/EPA supplementation reduced the number of days with illness at school, and when combined with iron, it prevented the increased morbidity (mostly respiratory) caused by iron supplementation alone.
population_specificity: Iron-deficient South African schoolchildren aged 6-11 years with low fish intake.
effective_dosage: Oral supplements (DHA/EPA mixture) administered 4 times per week (exact dosage not specified in abstract).
interactions: Significant interaction noted between iron and DHA/EPA, where DHA/EPA mitigated the adverse effects of iron supplementation on morbidity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of DHA supplementation on breast milk and plasma fatty acid composition in lactating women and their infants.
results_summary: DHA supplementation significantly increased breast milk and maternal plasma DHA levels compared to placebo, and improved infant plasma fatty acid ratios linked to brain development.
population_specificity: Lactating women 4-6 weeks post-partum and their infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to propose mechanisms by which docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) influences serotonin receptor action and brain function, particularly in neuropsychiatric disorders.
results_summary: The study suggests that DHA enhances serotonin receptor function by increasing postsynaptic neuron membrane fluidity, potentially improving cognitive and behavioral outcomes in disorders like ADHD, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia. It also highlights that insufficient DHA levels, alongside genetic and developmental factors, may contribute to dysfunctional serotonin activity.
population_specificity: General population with potential neuropsychiatric disorders (e.g., ADHD, bipolar disorder, schizophrenia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether n-3 PUFA supplementation during pregnancy modifies placental PUFA composition, SPM accumulation, and inflammatory gene expression.
results_summary: Supplementation increased placental DHA levels and SPM precursors but did not significantly alter EPA levels or most inflammatory gene expression, except for a 14-fold increase in TNFα expression.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (n=51) from 20-week gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anti-inflammatory effects of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and its bioactive metabolites, particularly in relation to asthma and allergic diseases.
results_summary: The study found that DHA and its metabolites (e.g., resolvins, protectins) exhibit protective effects against airway inflammation and may help resolve chronic inflammation, particularly in asthma. Epidemiological and observational studies suggest a link between reduced fish oil intake and increased asthma/allergic disease prevalence.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, lactating mothers, infants, children, and adults (general population with focus on asthma/allergy susceptibility).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of DHA on metabolic diseases (cardiovascular diseases, obesity, and T2DM) and its role in neurodevelopment and cognitive processes across different life stages.
results_summary: DHA supplementation was associated with reduced incidence of stroke and atherosclerosis, lower body weight, and decreased T2DM prevalence, suggesting it may inhibit metabolic pathologies and serve as a dietary protector throughout life. Efficacy depended on dose, duration, sex, and age.
population_specificity: General human population across life stages (childhood, adolescence, adulthood, later life).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between FADS SNPs and DHA/ARA status in pregnant women before and after DHA supplementation.
results_summary: Women homozygous for the minor allele of FADS1rs174533 had lower DHA and ARA status at baseline. DHA supplementation increased DHA status across all genotypes, but decreased ARA status in minor allele homozygotes.
population_specificity: 205 pregnant women in their last two trimesters.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of DHA intake, alone or combined with EPA, on specific memory domains (episodic, working, and semantic) in healthy adults aged 18 and older.
results_summary: DHA/EPA supplementation significantly improved episodic memory in adults with mild memory complaints, and doses >1 g/day improved episodic memory regardless of baseline cognitive status. Semantic and working memory changes were significant with DHA, but no between-group differences were detected.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 18 and older, including those with mild memory complaints but free of neurologic disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the biological effects of maternal n-3 PUFA supplementation, including docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), are mediated through DNA methylation in CD4(+) T-cells.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in DNA methylation profiles between the supplement and control groups, with effect sizes below 5%. While suggestive dose-dependent effects were noted, they did not reach genome-wide significance, indicating minimal impact of n-3 PUFA exposure on T-cell methylation.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their neonates (70 cord blood samples analyzed).
study_duration: Duration of supplementation not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether DHA supplementation reduces perceived stress and cortisol response to stressors in pregnant African American women living in low-income environments.
results_summary: Women receiving DHA reported lower perceived stress at 30 weeks and showed reduced cortisol output in response to stress. DHA supplementation appeared to modulate stress hormone responses during late pregnancy.
population_specificity: African American women, 16-21 weeks pregnant, living in low-income urban environments.
study_duration: From enrollment (16-21 weeks gestation) to 30 weeks gestation (approximately 9-14 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in cognition and dementia, specifically its effects on memory in healthy adults and cognitive outcomes in ApoE4-negative Alzheimer's patients.
results_summary: The MIDAS Study found DHA improved episodic memory in healthy adults with mild memory complaints, while the ADCS AD trial showed no overall benefit in primary outcomes but noted cognitive improvement in ApoE4-negative patients. The abstract suggests ApoE may influence DHA's brain transport and function.
population_specificity: Healthy adults with mild memory complaints (MIDAS Study) and Alzheimer's patients, stratified by ApoE4 status (ADCS AD trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) could prevent or alleviate fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) development.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that DHA, among other nutrients, may help mitigate FASD-related malformations, but further research is needed to confirm efficacy and determine optimal dosages.
population_specificity: Prenatal (animal models and human FASD-related research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore strategies for increasing EPA and DHA intake among active duty military personnel, addressing challenges like dosage, cost efficiency, and stability.
results_summary: The abstract discusses potential strategies for increasing EPA and DHA intake in military diets but does not present specific results on Docosahexaenoic Acid's effects.
population_specificity: Active duty military personnel

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementary docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), combined with multiple micronutrients, could improve environmental enteropathy (EE) in rural Malawian children.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with DHA and micronutrients modestly improved lactulose:mannitol (L:M) ratios, indicating a transient amelioration of EE. The effect was statistically significant but clinically modest.
population_specificity: Rural Malawian children aged 1-3 years with abnormal baseline L:M ratios.
effective_dosage: Provided the Recommended Dietary Intake for DHA (exact amount not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the benefits of omega-3 fatty acids, particularly docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), in human health and the challenges of incorporating them into foods, with a focus on nanoemulsions as a potential solution.
results_summary: The study highlights the health benefits of omega-3 fatty acids, especially DHA, for brain development and cardiovascular health, and discusses the challenges of incorporating them into foods due to solubility and stability issues. Nanoemulsions are proposed as an effective method to enhance stability and bioavailability of omega-3 fatty acids in liquid food systems.
population_specificity: General human population (not specified further)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the imbalance between omega-6 and omega-3 fatty acids in modern diets and the potential benefits of increasing EPA and DHA intake.
results_summary: The study found that modern diets are high in omega-6 and low in omega-3 fatty acids, leading to metabolic competition. Increasing EPA and DHA intake reduces tissue omega-6 levels but does not address the underlying dietary imbalance.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of dietary patterns).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the unique needs of premature infants regarding DHA, review current LCPUFA recommendations, and explore ways to address DHA deficiency to improve morbidity and mortality.
results_summary: The study highlights that DHA is essential for neurodevelopment and vision, with premature infants being deficient due to incomplete in utero accretion. Evidence suggests DHA may protect against diseases like bronchopulmonary dysplasia and retinopathy of prematurity.
population_specificity: Very low birth weight (VLBW) premature infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the bioactive lipid epoxide mediators generated from docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) by CYP enzymes and their potential effects on angiogenic and inflammatory signaling pathways.
results_summary: The study found that DHA-derived epoxides can be more potent than arachidonic acid-derived EETs, with potential anti-hypertensive and anti-inflammatory effects when soluble epoxide hydrolase (sEH) is inhibited. However, the actions of these epoxides are under-investigated, and more studies are needed to understand their full spectrum of effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general biochemical and physiological context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) status at delivery influenced changes in maternal vitamin D status from mid-pregnancy to birth.
results_summary: The study found that DHA status at delivery did not have a significant effect on the change in plasma 25(OH)D concentration between mid-pregnancy and birth. Other factors like season and mid-pregnancy vitamin D levels were more influential.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in the United States (n = 193).
study_duration: From mid-pregnancy (8-20 weeks gestation) to birth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 supplements, including docosahexaenoic acid, inhibit airway sensitivity to inhaled mannitol and improve bronchial hyperresponsiveness in people with mild to moderate asthma.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 supplementation, including docosahexaenoic acid, did not improve bronchial hyperresponsiveness to mannitol, reduce sputum eosinophil counts, or inhibit urinary mast cell mediators in asthma patients. However, it significantly lowered blood triglyceride levels and altered serum fatty acids and eicosanoid metabolites.
population_specificity: Adults (mean age 28 years) with mild to moderate asthma and bronchial hyperresponsiveness to mannitol (n=23; 14 men, half on regular inhaled corticosteroids).
effective_dosage: 2.0 g/d docosahexaenoic acid (combined with 4.0 g/d eicosapentaenoic acid).
study_duration: 3 weeks per treatment period, separated by a 3-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prenatal DHA supplementation could modulate epigenetic states at birth, specifically focusing on DNA methylation at IGF2 and H19 imprinted regions.
results_summary: The study found that DHA supplementation led to significant changes in DNA methylation levels at IGF2 P3 and H19 DMR, with effects varying by maternal BMI and preterm status. These findings suggest DHA may influence epigenetic mechanisms related to child growth and development.
population_specificity: Mexican pregnant women, supplemented from gestation week 18-22 to parturition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral supplementation with docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) could modulate inflammatory responses in patients undergoing elective colorectal cancer surgery.
results_summary: The study found that DHA and EPA supplementation significantly increased anti-inflammatory markers (LTB5, 5-HEPE) and decreased pro-inflammatory markers (LTB4, 5-HETE) in neutrophils, but did not reduce postoperative complications.
population_specificity: Patients referred for elective colorectal cancer surgery (n=148).
effective_dosage: 1.0 g DHA and 2.0 g EPA per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the adequacy of DHA intake in toddlers and highlight the need for improved DHA supplementation in early childhood nutrition.
results_summary: The study found that DHA intake in toddlers often falls short of nutritional recommendations, particularly in Hungary where breast milk DHA levels are notably low. Encouraging fish consumption during complementary feeding was suggested to improve DHA supply.
population_specificity: Toddlers and young children in Europe, with specific mention of Hungary.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with omega-3 PUFAs, including docosahexaenoic acid, could reduce systemic inflammation in chronic kidney disease patients on dialysis.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 PUFA supplementation reduced LPS-induced PBMC expression of RANTES and MCP-1 but had no significant effect on serum inflammatory markers like C-reactive protein, interleukin-6, and procalcitonin.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease patients on dialysis (CKD5D), predominantly African-American (74%) and male (79%).
effective_dosage: 2.9 g of eicosapentaenoic acid plus docosahexaenoic acid (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increased intake of stearidonic acid (SDA) from Echium oil could enhance endogenous EPA synthesis and lower serum triacylglycerol concentrations, indirectly assessing docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) effects.
results_summary: Echium oil increased EPA in red blood cell membranes but did not significantly affect serum triacylglycerol concentrations, DHA levels, or the omega-3 index.
population_specificity: Healthy overweight and slightly obese subjects (n=32 after dropouts).
effective_dosage: 10 g of Echium oil daily (providing 1.2 g of SDA).
study_duration: 6 weeks per intervention with a 14-day washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify dietary and non-dietary factors influencing DHA levels in umbilical cord blood at delivery.
results_summary: DHA concentrations in cord blood varied 3-4 fold, with maternal DHA supplement intake and gestational age explaining 21% and 16% of the variation, respectively. Over 65% of the variation remained unexplained, suggesting other factors influence cord blood DHA levels.
population_specificity: Pregnant women participating in the DOMInO randomized controlled trial (n=1571).
effective_dosage: Not specified (referred to as "DHA-rich intervention supplement capsules").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of EPA and DHA supplementation on whole-body resting metabolic rate (RMR) and skeletal muscle fat metabolism proteins in humans.
results_summary: Omega-3 supplementation modestly increased RMR (5.3%) but had no effect on fat oxidation or most skeletal muscle fat metabolism proteins, except for an 11% increase in UCP3. The effect on RMR was variable and lost when normalized for body mass.
population_specificity: Recreationally active young males.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the EPA and DHA content in commercial fish, krill, and algal oil supplements to assess compliance with label claims.
results_summary: The study found that over 70% of supplements did not contain the stated label amount of EPA or DHA, with only 21% meeting EPA claims and 25% meeting DHA claims. Algal oil supplements generally had higher DHA content but lower EPA compared to fish- and krill-based supplements.
population_specificity: Commercial fish, krill, and algal oil supplements (47 tested).
effective_dosage: Not specified (analyzed content per mg/g of oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether DHA supplementation could reduce inflammatory cytokine production in infants at high genetic risk for Type 1 Diabetes.
results_summary: DHA supplementation significantly increased infant RBC DHA levels but did not consistently reduce inflammatory cytokines. However, breast-fed DHA-treated infants showed lower hsCRP levels compared to formula-fed infants at 12 months.
population_specificity: Infants with a high genetic risk for Type 1 Diabetes, including prenatal (last trimester) and postnatal (first 5 months) supplementation groups.
study_duration: Supplementation began either in the last trimester of pregnancy or the first 5 months after birth, with follow-up until 36 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the vascular effects of DHA-only supplementation versus EPA + DHA during postprandial lipemia and assess the impact of linoleic acid-enriched meals.
results_summary: The study found that DHA-rich algal oil (AO) inhibited the typical postprandial decrease in plasma nonesterified fatty acids and reduced 8-isoprostane F2α levels, while EPA + DHA-rich fish oil (FO) increased them. However, these differences did not consistently affect postprandial vascular function or lipemia.
population_specificity: 16 healthy men aged 35-70 years with higher than optimal fasting triacylglycerol concentrations (mean ± SD triacylglycerol, 1.9 ± 0.5 mmol/L).
effective_dosage: 5 g DHA (algal oil) and 5 g EPA + DHA (fish oil) per high-fat meal.
study_duration: Single-meal intervention (acute effects measured over 3 hours postprandially).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether DHA supplementation reduces inflammatory and muscle damage responses to acute eccentric exercise and the initiation of resistance training.
results_summary: DHA significantly reduced serum CK (12.5%) and IL-6 (32%) in the acute phase but did not affect strength or DOMS. Over the 17-day period, DHA showed a trend toward reduced DOMS and CK, though not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 41 untrained men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of study characteristics, particularly concomitant statin therapy, on the results of randomized controlled trials evaluating omega-3 PUFA supplementation for cardiovascular prevention.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 PUFA supplementation had no significant effect on total mortality or myocardial infarction but marginally reduced cardiovascular mortality. Lower statin use in the control group and a higher DHA/EPA ratio were associated with greater reductions in total mortality.
population_specificity: 77,776 patients (38,910 receiving PUFA, 38,866 controls) in randomized controlled trials.
interactions: Statin use may mitigate the beneficial effects of PUFA supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early DHA supplementation during pregnancy could reduce the incidence of deep placentation disorders, such as preterm birth, preeclampsia, and fetal growth restriction.
results_summary: Recent randomized controlled trials showed inconsistent benefits of DHA supplementation for preventing deep placentation disorders, but most indicated a lower risk of early preterm birth. The study hypothesizes that early DHA supplementation may reduce these disorders, potentially offering a safe and effective preventive strategy.
population_specificity: Pregnant women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether marine and plant-derived omega-3 fatty acids, including docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), could slow the decline of kidney function in post-myocardial infarction patients.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with 400 mg/day of EPA-DHA resulted in a modest but statistically significant reduction in kidney function decline compared to placebo, with no significant effects observed for other omega-3 combinations.
population_specificity: 2,344 post-myocardial infarction patients aged 60-80 years (81% men).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the sex-dependent effects of DHA-rich oil supplementation on procoagulant and platelet activity in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that DHA supplementation reduced platelet aggregation in females but did not significantly alter coagulation parameters, while EPA showed more pronounced effects in males. The sex-specific effects suggest differential cardioprotective benefits of DHA and EPA.
population_specificity: 94 healthy adults (41 males, 53 females)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) influences phosphatidylserine (PS) synthesis in neuronal membranes and its potential effects on PS-dependent signaling and protein function.
results_summary: The study found that DHA promotes PS synthesis in neuronal membranes, potentially enhancing PS-dependent signaling and protein function, which supports neuronal survival and differentiation. Ethanol was noted to decrease DHA-promoted PS synthesis, which may contribute to its deleterious effects. PS supplementation improved some memory functions in cognitively impaired subjects, though the mechanism remains unclear.
population_specificity: Neuronal tissues and cognitively impaired subjects (specific population details not provided).
interactions: Ethanol was noted to decrease DHA-promoted PS synthesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether DHA supplementation combined with low-dose aspirin could reduce periodontitis in humans.
results_summary: DHA supplementation significantly improved periodontal outcomes, including reduced pocket depth and gingival index, and lowered inflammatory markers (hsCRP and IL-1β) in gingival crevicular fluid, though systemic hsCRP and IL-6 were unaffected.
population_specificity: 55 adults with moderate periodontitis (46 completed the trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of DHA supplementation on plasma oxidative balance and anti-inflammatory markers after training and acute exercise in football players.
results_summary: DHA supplementation increased plasma DHA availability and PGE2 levels, indicating anti-inflammatory effects, but did not significantly alter oxidative damage biomarkers. The antioxidant system was sufficient to prevent oxidative damage induced by acute exercise.
population_specificity: Fifteen male football players.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of DHA supplementation on plasma cytokine levels and PBMC cytokine production after exercise in soccer players.
results_summary: DHA supplementation increased erythrocyte DHA content and reduced TNFα and IL6 production by stimulated PBMCs, but did not alter basal plasma cytokines. Acute exercise increased IL6 and PBMC cytokine production, which was attenuated by DHA.
population_specificity: 15 male soccer players
effective_dosage: Almond-based beverage enriched with DHA (exact dosage not specified)

study_goal: To determine if docosahexaenoic acid-enriched fish oil supplementation corrects red cell membrane lipid anomalies in pregnant women with Type 2 diabetes and their neonates, and affects fetal body composition.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation increased docosahexaenoic acid levels in red cell membranes of pregnant women with Type 2 diabetes and their neonates but had no effect on fetal or neonatal body composition. The supplement also prevented the decline of maternal docosahexaenoic acid during pregnancy.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with Type 2 diabetes and healthy pregnant women, along with their neonates.
study_duration: From the first trimester until delivery

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between blood omega-3 fatty acid levels (including docosahexaenoic acid) and clinical factors such as age, smoking history, and fish oil supplementation in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that higher blood omega-3 fatty acid levels (O3I) were associated with older age, fish oil supplementation, and elevated body mass index, while a history of smoking correlated with lower O3I levels. The results suggest that O3I is a reliable marker of dietary omega-3 intake in PAD patients.
population_specificity: 111 patients with peripheral arterial disease (ankle-brachial index <0.9 and claudication symptoms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the relationship between DHA and cognition across different life stages, including the perinatal period, young adulthood, adulthood, and neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's.
results_summary: Human studies did not show consistent memory improvement with DHA supplementation, while animal studies demonstrated positive effects, possibly due to the use of n-3 PUFA-deficient controls. In animal models of Alzheimer's, n-3 LCPUFA was generally found to attenuate cognitive impairment.
population_specificity: Humans (perinatal to adulthood) and animal models (including Alzheimer's disease models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fish oil supplementation, including docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), on cortical metabolite concentrations and depressive symptoms in adolescents with major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The study found that fish oil supplementation increased erythrocyte EPA and DHA levels while decreasing AA, with significant reductions in depressive symptoms in the high-dose group. There were subtle changes in metabolite concentrations (Glx, mI, Cho) in the DLPFC, though no significant baseline-endpoint changes were observed.
population_specificity: Adolescents with major depressive disorder (MDD)
effective_dosage: Low dose (2.4 g/day) and high dose (16.2 g/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 PUFA supplementation, including docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), could reduce tobacco craving and daily smoking in regular smokers.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with 2040 mg DHA/day alongside EPA significantly decreased daily smoking and tobacco craving after cigarette cue exposure, with effects persisting for a month post-treatment. This suggests omega-3 PUFAs may help manage tobacco consumption.
population_specificity: Regular cigarette smokers (n=48)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether DHA supplementation in pregnant women could increase the quantity and viability of hematopoietic stem cells in umbilical cord blood samples.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study design but does not report results regarding DHA's effects on cell number or viability in umbilical cord blood.
population_specificity: Pregnant women enrolled from the 20th or 28th week of estimated gestational age.
effective_dosage: 250 mg DHA or placebo (olive oil) once daily.
study_duration: From the 20th or 28th week up to the 40th week of estimated gestational age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk and its dietary sources, particularly in vegetarians and vegans.
results_summary: The study found that high intakes of EPA and DHA (3-5 g/d) had favorable effects on CVD risk factors, but meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials showed no clear benefit for CVD prevention. Vegans and vegetarians had lower DHA levels but lower CVD risk compared to omnivores.
population_specificity: Vegetarians, vegans, and omnivores.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the potential health benefits and safety of α-Linolenic Acid (ALA) as a precursor to docosahexaenoic acid (DHA).
results_summary: The study found that ALA has reported cardiovascular-protective, anti-cancer, neuro-protective, anti-osteoporotic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidative effects, but its benefits for cardiovascular disease risk factors remain inconclusive. No serious adverse effects were reported, though evidence on increased prostate cancer risk is not conclusive.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) could serve as a recovery aid or prophylactic measure for mild traumatic brain injuries (mTBIs) by examining preclinical evidence and potential mechanisms.
results_summary: Preclinical studies suggest that DHA, whether consumed before or after mTBI, improves functional outcomes like spatial learning and memory. DHA appears to influence multiple pathological molecular signaling pathways post-injury, though clinical confirmation in humans is needed.
population_specificity: Preclinical models (not specified if animal or human, but likely animal given the context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-dose docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) could slow the progression of X-linked retinitis pigmentosa, as measured by cone electroretinography (ERG).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the rate of cone ERG functional loss between the DHA and placebo groups. While DHA supplementation was safe with no severe adverse effects, it did not effectively slow disease progression.
population_specificity: Male patients diagnosed with X-linked retinitis pigmentosa (n=60 in the modified intent-to-treat cohort).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of omega-3 PUFA, particularly EPA and DHA, in treating depressive disorders, comparing mono-therapy versus adjuvant therapy and assessing factors influencing outcomes.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significant clinical benefit of omega-3 PUFA, especially EPA-rich formulations, in patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) and depressive symptoms without MDD. Efficacy was higher when used as adjuvant therapy rather than mono-therapy, with no significant influence from study size, baseline severity, or duration.
population_specificity: Patients with DSM-defined MDD, depressive symptoms without MDD, bipolar disorder, and other depressive conditions (excluding young populations, perinatal depression, and non-depressive primary diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pro-apoptotic effects of an ethanol extract from Evodia rutaecarpa (EEER) in HeLa human cervical cancer cells and elucidate its molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: EEER induced apoptosis in HeLa cells via caspase-dependent pathways, suppressed Bcl-2 expression, disrupted mitochondrial membrane potential, and activated AMPK signaling, suggesting potential anti-cancer effects.
population_specificity: HeLa human cervical cancer cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively characterize the chemical constituents of Evodia rutaecarpa extract using advanced analytical techniques.
results_summary: The study identified 3 acylgluconic acids, 3 flavonol glycosides, 6 limonoids, and 24 alkaloids in Evodia rutaecarpa, including 6 previously unreported quinolone alkaloids. The findings enhance understanding of its chemical profile and support further pharmacological research.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or chemical analysis study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential targets of berberine and evodiamine from Evodia rutaecarpa in Alzheimer's disease (AD) and analyze their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study summarized potential biomarkers and targets of berberine and evodiamine in AD, proposing a compound-targets-pathway network to clarify their mechanisms. It also discussed limitations in current TCM research for AD prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research, not a clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the pharmacological actions, toxicological effects, and molecular targets of rutaecarpine (from Evodia rutaecarpa) in cardiovascular disease prevention and treatment.
results_summary: Rutaecarpine demonstrated broad pharmacological effects, including cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, and metabolic benefits, with identified molecular targets such as TRPV1, CGRP, and AMPK. Derivatives like bromorutaecarpine showed improved safety and protective effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cardiovascular disease context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory effects of evodiamine and rutaecarpine (components of Evodia rutaecarpa) on TRPV1 channels and their potential as partial agonists or antagonists.
results_summary: Evodiamine and rutaecarpine partially activated TRPV1 but with lower efficacy than capsaicin. Evodiamine, but not rutaecarpine, competitively inhibited capsaicin-induced TRPV1 currents and desensitized proton-induced currents, suggesting distinct mechanisms of action.
population_specificity: TRPV1-expressing HEK293 cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer effects of Evodia rutaecarpa (ER) and its components, particularly limonin, on ovarian cancer cell lines, including cisplatin-resistant cells.
results_summary: ER and limonin significantly reduced the viability of ovarian cancer cells by inducing apoptosis via the p53 signaling pathway, and limonin reversed cisplatin resistance in SKOV-3 cells.
population_specificity: Ovarian cancer cell lines (SKOV-3, A2780, RMUG-S, and cisplatin-resistant SKOV-3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory activity of a 70% ethanol extract of Evodia rutaecarpa (EEER) against benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and its underlying mechanisms in BPH-1 cells.
results_summary: EEER exhibited potent 5α-reductase inhibitory activity, reduced cell viability, and induced apoptosis in BPH-1 cells via caspase-8- and caspase-3-dependent pathways. The extract also downregulated proliferative markers like PCNA, cyclin D1, and phosphor-ERK1/2.
population_specificity: BPH-1 cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of evodiamine (Evo) on colonic motility in rats and the underlying mechanisms, focusing on L-type calcium channels, nitric oxide, and cholecystokinin receptor 1 (CCK1R).
results_summary: Evo inhibited spontaneous muscle contractions in rat colon, primarily by inhibiting L-type calcium channels in smooth muscle cells. The relaxant effect was partly mediated by NO and CCK1R, but enteric neurons played a minor role.
population_specificity: Rats (colonic muscle and smooth muscle cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent research on evodiamine's anti-cancer activity and highlight its molecular mechanisms over the past decade.
results_summary: The study found that evodiamine, a major constituent of Evodia rutaecarpa, exhibits anti-cancer effects by inhibiting tumor cell proliferation, invasion, and metastasis, as well as inducing apoptosis in various tumor cell lines. The review highlights its potential as a chemotherapy adjuvant to enhance efficacy and reduce side effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies, various tumor cell lines)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective mechanism of mucoadhesive microspheres loaded with alkaloids from Evodia rutaecarpa and Coptis chinensis on ethanol-induced acute gastric mucosal injury in rats.
results_summary: The mucoadhesive microspheres sustained drug release for over 12 hours, reduced gastric injury by decreasing mucosal lesions and inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-1β), and increased mucus production in the gastric mucosa. The microspheres demonstrated high retention in the stomach and exerted gastroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Ethanol-induced gastric mucosal injury rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anti-inflammatory and anti-infectious effects of Evodia rutaecarpa and its bioactive components, as well as their potential therapeutic applications for various conditions.
results_summary: The study highlights Evodia rutaecarpa's potential benefits for treating endotoxaemia, obesity, diabetes, Alzheimer's disease, and its roles as a cardiovascular and gastrointestinal protective agent, analgesic, antioxidant, and anti-infectious agent. The stimulation of calcitonin gene-related peptide release may explain some of its therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate active compounds in Evodia rutaecarpa that inhibit aldose reductase, potentially useful for treating diabetic complications.
results_summary: The study identified rhetsinine as an active compound in Evodia rutaecarpa, which inhibited aldose reductase with an IC50 of 24.1 µM and reduced sorbitol accumulation by 79.3% at 100 µM, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for diabetic complications.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or animal study implied by methodology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the synergistic anticancer effect and mechanism of Zuojinwan (a combination of Coptis chinensis and Evodia rutaecarpa) in inhibiting tumor growth.
results_summary: Zuojinwan significantly induced cancer cell apoptosis, increased tumor growth inhibition (50.54%), extended life span (64.91%), elevated TNF-alpha levels (1.04 ng/mL), and modulated serum tumor marker activities and gene expression (Bax and p53) compared to single-component treatments.
population_specificity: Mice with S180 tumors.
effective_dosage: Not specified (Zuojinwan ratio: 6:1 w/w Coptis chinensis to Evodia rutaecarpa).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rutaecarpine from Evodia rutaecarpa induces NAD(P)H:quinone reductase (QR) activity and gene expression via AP-1 activation.
results_summary: Rutaecarpine significantly increased QR enzyme activity and mRNA expression in a dose-dependent manner and activated AP-1-mediated luciferase expression, suggesting it enhances QR gene expression through AP-1 transactivation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or cell-based study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess potential herb-drug interactions between Evodia rutaecarpa (and its preparation Wu-Chu-Yu-Tang) and theophylline in rats.
results_summary: The study found that pretreatment with Evodia rutaecarpa extract and Wu-Chu-Yu-Tang significantly decreased theophylline blood levels in a dose-dependent manner, suggesting herb-drug interaction via metabolic induction.
population_specificity: Rats
effective_dosage: Evodia rutaecarpa extract (1 and 2 g/kg/day, p.o.); Wu-Chu-Yu-Tang (1 and 5 g/kg/day)
interactions: Theophylline (decreased blood levels due to metabolic induction)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute toxicity and mutagenic risk of water and 70% ethanol extracts of Evodia rutaecarpa to assess its safety for human consumption.
results_summary: The study found that both extracts had an LD50 greater than 10.0 g/kg, indicating low acute toxicity, and showed no genotoxicity in Ames, micronucleus, or sperm aberration tests. No adverse effects or deaths were observed at tested doses.
population_specificity: Healthy Kunming strain mice (male and female, varying weights).
study_duration: Acute toxicity: 7 days; genotoxicity: 5 days (sperm aberration), 24h intervals (micronucleus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize the chemical constituents of Evodia rutaecarpa, including the isolation and structural determination of its alkaloids.
results_summary: Fourteen compounds were isolated from Evodia rutaecarpa, ten of which were identified, including a new alkaloid named evodianinine. The study focused on chemical analysis rather than biological or clinical effects.
population_specificity: Not applicable (chemical analysis, no human or animal subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacokinetic interaction of theophylline with rutaecarpine and assess its effects on CYP1A2 activity and theophylline pharmacokinetics.
results_summary: Rutaecarpine treatment significantly increased CYP1A2 catalytic activity and theophylline clearance in rats, reducing theophylline's AUC, MRT, and half-life by 68-70%. The study suggests potential adverse effects when rutaecarpine is used with theophylline.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats
interactions: Concomitant use with theophylline may lead to adverse effects due to increased clearance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Evodia rutaecarpa could prevent circulatory failure, organ dysfunction, and excessive nitric oxide production in a rat model of septic shock induced by endotoxin.
results_summary: Pretreatment with Evodia rutaecarpa dose-dependently prevented circulatory failure, vascular hyporeactivity, liver dysfunction, and reduced nitric oxide overproduction in endotoxaemic rats, likely by inhibiting inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) activity.
population_specificity: Anaesthetized rats challenged with endotoxin (Escherichia coli lipopolysaccharide).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect and underlying mechanisms of rutaecarpine (from Evodia rutaecarpa) on the relaxation of the internal anal sphincter in rabbits and humans.
results_summary: Rutaecarpine produced a concentration-dependent relaxation effect on the internal anal sphincter in rabbits and humans, which was not mediated by the NO-cGMP pathway but appeared to involve calcium ion mechanisms. The effect was more prominent in human tissue.
population_specificity: Rabbit and human internal anal sphincter muscle strips.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of rutaecarpine, a compound from Evodia rutaecarpa, by examining its inhibition of COX-2 and COX-1 activity in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Rutaecarpine inhibited COX-2 and COX-1 dependent PGD2 generation in bone marrow-derived mast cells and COX-2-dependent PGE2 production in transfected HEK293 cells, showing dose-dependent effects. It also demonstrated in vivo anti-inflammatory activity in a rat model of carrageenan-induced paw edema.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats and cultured bone marrow-derived mast cells (BMMC).
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentrations used in vitro: up to 30 µM; in vivo dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Paw volumes measured 5 hours after carrageenan injection (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of rutaecarpine, a main alkaloid in Evodia rutaecarpa, on hepatic and renal cytochrome P450 (CYP)-dependent monooxygenase activities in mice.
results_summary: Rutaecarpine significantly increased hepatic and renal CYP1A1 and CYP1A2 activities, indicating it is a potent inducer of these enzymes, but had no effect on other CYP activities. The treatment did not alter CYP3A levels in the liver, and these CYPs were undetectable in the kidneys.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Evodia rutaecarpa extracts on drug-metabolizing enzymes (CYP, UGT, GST) in mice to evaluate potential drug interactions.
results_summary: Methanol and aqueous extracts of Evodia rutaecarpa increased hepatic drug-metabolizing enzyme activities, particularly CYP1A1, CYP1A2, and CYP2B, with methanol extract showing broader effects. The alkaloids rutaecarpine, evodiamine, and dehydroevodiamine contributed to increased EROD activity.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice
effective_dosage: 2 g/kg for extracts, 25 mg/kg for alkaloids

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanisms underlying rutaecarpine-induced vasodilation in isolated rat mesenteric arterial ring segments.
results_summary: Rutaecarpine produced dose-dependent vasorelaxation, which was endothelium-dependent and involved nitric oxide and guanylyl cyclase, but not muscarinic, histamine H1, or alpha 2-adrenoceptors. It also reduced intracellular calcium-related contractions in vascular smooth muscle.
population_specificity: Isolated rat mesenteric arterial ring segments

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antianoxic potential of evodiamine from Evodia rutaecarpa compared to vinpocetine using animal models of anoxia.
results_summary: Evodiamine was equivalent to vinpocetine in the KCN-induced anoxia model but superior in the low-pressure-induced anoxia model. Its effectiveness increased when combined with physostigmine, suggesting a cholinergic mechanism.
population_specificity: Mice
interactions: Combined treatment with physostigmine enhanced effectiveness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pharmacological applications, anti-cancer mechanisms, and limitations of evodiamine from Evodia rutaecarpa, focusing on improving its delivery via nanocarriers.
results_summary: Evodiamine exhibits multiple pharmacological effects, including anti-cancer activity, but its clinical use is limited by poor solubility, bioavailability, and toxicity. Nanocarriers show promise in enhancing its therapeutic potential while reducing side effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and analyze the research progress, mechanisms, and toxicity of evodiamine (EVO) from Evodia rutaecarpa in treating digestive system diseases.
results_summary: EVO demonstrated positive effects on various digestive system diseases in both cellular and animal experiments, though some mechanisms and toxicity remain controversial. The study identified multiple potential pathways through which EVO may exert its effects, but further research is needed to confirm its benefits and safety.
population_specificity: Animal models (e.g., colorectal cancer, gastric ulcers, liver cancer) and cellular lines (e.g., SGC7901, HT29, HCT-116, HepG2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of Hezhong granules (containing Evodia rutaecarpa) in preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) in patients with advanced colorectal cancer.
results_summary: Hezhong granules showed significant improvements in preventing delayed CINV, with a 20% increase in complete response rates and improved quality of life. No serious adverse events were attributed to the herbal medicine.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced colorectal cancer receiving fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (Hezhong granules were used alongside standard antiemetics).
study_duration: Two cycles of chemotherapy (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively review the pharmacological activities, mechanisms, and structure-activity relationships of Evodiamine (EVO) derivatives derived from Evodia rutaecarpa.
results_summary: The study found that EVO and its derivatives exhibit diverse biological activities, including antitumor, anti-Alzheimer's, and anti-pulmonary hypertension effects, acting through multiple mechanisms on various proteins. However, EVO's moderate activity and poor physicochemical properties limit its clinical application.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of pharmacological studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential therapeutic effects of rutaecarpine, an alkaloid from Evodia rutaecarpa, on two different subtypes of breast cancer cells.
results_summary: Rutaecarpine significantly inhibited the growth of both MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells, inducing apoptotic cell death and G0/G1 arrest, with more profound effects in MCF-7 cells.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cell lines (MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current studies on evodiamine, the main component of Evodia rutaecarpa, focusing on its pharmacology, toxicology, pharmacokinetics, and clinical applications.
